abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Third Highway Project
            for Guinea was marginally satisfactory. The project achieved
            some of its objectives, its impact on institutional
            development was partially successful, sustainability is
            uncertain, and the performance of both the Bank and Borrower
            was marginally satisfactory. Several lessons can be learned
            from this project. First, at the time of appraisal, closer
            attention needs to be given to accurate assessment of work
            volume and definition of realistic and appropriate physical
            standards. Second, detailed engineering studies should be
            available before credit effectiveness to allow an early
            start-up of the project. Third, detailed terms of reference
            for training should be prepared in order to implement an
            adequate training program and be able to assess its
            execution. Fourth, more resources should be allocated by the
            Bank for supervision. Fifth, the impact of a significant
            change in the political, economical, and financial situation
            of the country on the project should be assessed and the
            project should be redefined on the basis of this assessment.
            Sixth, detailed review of documents and rigorous adherence
            to the Bank's procurement guidelines do not in
            themselves guarantee a good performance of the contractor.
            Finally, setting up new institutions or reforming existing
            ones requires careful and time-phased design of components.
